sn46.6:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāketa in the deer part at the Añjana Wood.
sn46.6:4.2: Then the wanderer Kuṇḍaliya went up to the Buddha,
sn46.6:4.4: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
sn46.6:4.6: “Master Gotama, I like to hang around the monasteries and visit the assemblies.
sn46.6:4.7: When I’ve finished breakfast, it’s my habit to
sn46.6:4.8: wander from monastery to monastery, from park to park.
sn46.6:4.9: There I see some ascetics and brahmins speaking for the sake of winning debates and finding fault.
sn46.6:4.10: But what benefit does Master Gotama live for?”
sn46.6:4.11: “The benefit the Realized One lives for, Kuṇḍaliya, is the fruit of knowledge and freedom.
sn46.6:5.1: “But what things must be developed and cultivated in order to fulfill knowledge and freedom?”
sn46.6:5.3: “But what things must be developed and cultivated in order to fulfill the seven awakening factors?”
sn46.6:5.5: “But what things must be developed and cultivated in order to fulfill the four kinds of mindfulness meditation?”
sn46.6:5.7: “But what things must be developed and cultivated in order to fulfill the three kinds of good conduct?”
sn46.6:6.1: And Kuṇḍaliya, how is sense restraint developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the three kinds of good conduct?
sn46.6:6.2: A mendicant sees an agreeable sight with their eye. They don’t desire it or enjoy it, and they don’t give rise to greed.
sn46.6:6.3: Their mind and body are steady internally, well settled and well freed.
sn46.6:6.4: But if they see a disagreeable sight they’re not dismayed; their mind isn’t hardened, dejected, or full of ill will.
sn46.6:6.5: Their mind and body are steady internally, well settled and well freed.
sn46.6:7.1: Furthermore, a mendicant hears a sound with the ear …
sn46.6:7.2: smells an agreeable odor with the nose …
sn46.6:7.3: tastes an agreeable flavor with the tongue …
sn46.6:7.4: feels an agreeable touch with the body …
sn46.6:7.5: cognizes an agreeable phenomenon with their mind. They don’t desire it or enjoy it, and they don’t give rise to greed.
sn46.6:7.6: Their mind and body are steady internally, well settled and well freed.
sn46.6:7.7: But if they cognize a disagreeable phenomenon they’re not dismayed; their mind isn’t hardened, dejected, or full of ill will.
sn46.6:7.8: Their mind and body are steady internally, well settled and well freed.
sn46.6:8.1: When a mendicants mind and body are steady internally, they’re well settled and well freed when it comes to both agreeable and disagreeable sights,
sn46.6:8.7: That’s how sense restraint is developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the three kinds of good conduct.
sn46.6:9.1: And how are the three kinds of good conduct developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the four kinds of mindfulness meditation?
sn46.6:9.2: A mendicant gives up bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and develops good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.
sn46.6:9.3: That’s how the three kinds of good conduct are developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn46.6:10.1: And how are the four kinds of mindfulness meditation developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the seven awakening factors?
sn46.6:10.2: A monastic meditates by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn46.6:10.3: They meditate by observing an aspect of feelings …
sn46.6:10.5: principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn46.6:10.6: That’s how the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the seven awakening factors.
sn46.6:11.1: And how are the seven awakening factors developed and cultivated so as to fulfill knowledge and freedom?
sn46.6:11.2: A mendicant develops the awakening-factors of mindfulness, investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, samādhi, and
sn46.6:11.3: equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.
sn46.6:11.4: That’s how the seven awakening factors are developed and cultivated so as to fulfill knowledge and freedom.”
sn46.6:12.1: When he said this, the wanderer Kuṇḍaliya said to the Buddha:
sn46.6:12.3: As if he was righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark
sn46.6:12.4: so people with good eyes can see what’s there,
sn46.6:12.5: Master Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.
sn46.6:12.6: I go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the Dharma, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
sn46.6:12.7: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
